section.title: What’s in a sentence?
section.para: What make up this sentence? The core of it is give. That is the relation describing how the other things are involved with each other, how they connect and relate. Those involved things are I, you and this. These could be said to be variable — they are not fixed with the relation give. Rather than giving you this I could give you that instead. Or maybe it is you who give me something, and we would still be describing a relationship of giving. We could say that the relation give has three variable places that we can fill with different things. Thus we can define give as such:
We could label the variable places more clearly, numbering them and using x which is commonly used to describe something unknown or unspecified:
This says that we have a variable (x) place 1 that is a donor, a place 2 that is a receiver and a place 3 that is a gift. They share the relation give.
The Lojban word for give is dunda. It has this definition:

blockquote.para: x1 [donor] gives/donates gift/present x2 to recipient/beneficiary x3 [without payment/exchange]

section.para: You might notice that the gift and receiver switched places here, which we represented in English by adding the preposition to.

We call definitions like these place structures, because they show the structure of the variable places we can fill. In Lojban, we call the relation a selbri and the variables sumti. We call the whole sentence a bridi. Linguists and logicians call the sentences predicate relationships, the variables arguments and the relations predicates or predicate relations.
